awd_titl_txt: Novel Structural Materials Through Microstructural Control  in Liquid Phase Sintering
awd_abstract_narration: This proposal examines microstructural evolution during                    supersolidus liquid phase sintering (SLPS).  This is a                          densification technique for powdered metals in which liquid forms               along grain boundaries causing particle disintegration, capillary-              induced rearrangement of grains, and solution reprecipitation.                  Included are considerations of the nature of liquid flow and the                particle disintegration mechanism related to initial particle                   composition, cooling rate, and microstructure.  Process variables               include temperature, particle size, heating rate, and pre-sinter                annealing.  Factors affecting the sintering behavior include                    wetting, pore filling, liquid film migration, and compact                       densification.  Several characterization techniques (optical and                electron microscopy, dilatometry, and differential thermal analysis             are employed to study the microstructural evolution and influence               of processing variables).  Sintering maps that show the significant             parameters are an output of the research.                                       %%%                                                                                  This process offers near net-shape forming capability for high             quality parts.  Potential applications include steam turbine                    blades, engine components, and tool steels.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
